fields.value: Public Opinion in the Islamic World on Terrorism, al Qaeda, and US Policies

authorAffiliation.value: Program on International Policy Attitudes (PIPA). University of Maryland. School of Public Policy.
Program on International Policy Attitudes (PIPA). University of Maryland. School of Public Policy.

dsDescriptionValue.value:
To deal with the threat posed by groups that use terrorist methods against Americans, in particular al Qaeda, the US is faced by more than the problem of the groups themselves. These groups operate in a larger society that provides them with some degree of support—enough to allow them to persist. The purpose of this study is to understand more deeply the nature and extent of this support, and also to determine how it is evolving. This points to a range of issues.  To operate, groups that use terrorism must be viewed as legitimate by some sector of society. For decades the United States has had an increased military presence in numerous Muslim countries. Attitudes toward US military forces are, of course, embedded in a broader set of perceptions of US goals in relat
ion to the Muslim world. These perceptions of US goals are in turn embedded in broader attitudes about the US government and how it operates in the world. Once the complex attitudes about America’s role and the methods that are used by groups like al Qaeda against America are understood, we can turn to the question of how people in Muslim countries feel about al Qaeda and groups that attack Americans. A central goal of al Qaeda is to make Muslim societies more ‘Islamist’, i.e., more aligned with traditional interpretations of Islam and Shari’a law. Finally, there is probably no more central front in the conflict between al Qaeda and the US than the status of governments in the Muslim world that are supported by the US: namely Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Jordan and Pakistan.  To answer these and other questions WorldPublicOpinion.org conducted an in-depth survey of public opinion in Egypt, Pakistan, and Indonesia. This is the second wave of surveys and was conducted between July 28 and September 6, 2008: the first was conducted in late 2006 and early 2007. The research was primarily supported by the START Consortium at the University of Maryland. Other scholars of the START Consortium participated in the development of the questionnaire for both waves.

fields.value: The survey was conducted between July 28th, 2008 and September 6th, 2008 and used in-home interviews based upon multi-stage probability samples. In Egypt (1,101 interviews), Indonesia (1,120 interviews), and Pakistan (1,200 interviews) national probability samples were conducted covering both urban and rural areas. These sample sizes had 95% confidence intervals of +/- 3 percentage points. The surveys were conducted by the same research agencies that conducted the first wave of START polling in late 2007 and early 2008 so that the two waves would be as comparable as possible. The sampling designs were also identical to the first wave of polling in these three countries. Note: Due to the addition of rural data and more refined weighting some of the 2006/2007 findings cited in this report are slightly different from those previously reported.

In Indonesia, the sample designs for Wave 1 and Wave 2 were identical across the two waves so weights need not be applied to the samples for such comparisons though the field agency in Indonesia has supplied demographic weights on the data file according to age and gender which target national parameters. The Egyptian population is approximately 55% rural and 45% urban.  To make direct comparisons between Wave 1 and Wave 2 in Egypt, it is necessary to weight the Wave 1 data proportionately to the population (and to Wave 2 which is self weighted 53.4% rural and 46.6% urban).  Weights for urban-rural and gender are attached to the data file of Egypt Wave 1 to enable comparisons between Wave 1 and Wave 2   In Pakistan and Indonesia, the sample designs were identical across the two waves so weights need not be applied to the samples for such comparisons though the field agency in Indonesia has supplied demographic weights on the data file which target national parameters. In Pakistan, the sample was not weighted.

In Egypt, the response rate was 93%. The field agent did not report any major difficulties with face-to-face interviews.  Respondents did not have a significant amount of discomfort with the questions asked during the interview. In Indonesia, the response rate was 43%. The field agent did not face any major difficulties during the fieldwork.  But, for certain areas such as in Aceh, Ambon, and East Java, they had to be more careful in interviewing the respondents. A few respondents did not want to answer certain questions, or they refused to be interviewed because they thought it was not safe for them to talk about Islam and America. In Pakistan, the response rate was 38%. The field agent did not face any major difficulties. Field agents did report discomfort with some questions asked in the study. Some interviews were discontinued when questions turned to Islam and terrorism.
